title: Griess algebra
text:
In <a href="mathematics">mathematics</a>, the Griess algebra is a <a href="commutative">commutative</a> <a href="Algebra%20over%20a%20field%23Non-associative%20algebras">non-associative algebra</a> on a <a href="real%20number">real</a> <a href="vector%20space">vector space</a> of <a href="dimension">dimension</a> 196884 that has the <a href="Monster%20group">Monster group</a> "M" as its <a href="automorphism%20group">automorphism group</a>. It is named after mathematician <a href="R.%20L.%20Griess">R. L. Griess</a>, who constructed it in 1980 and subsequently used it in 1982 to construct "M". The Monster fixes (vectorwise) a 1-space in this algebra and acts absolutely irreducibly on the 196883-dimensional <a href="orthogonal%20complement">orthogonal complement</a> of this 1-space.
Griess's construction was later simplified by <a href="Jacques%20Tits">Jacques Tits</a> and <a href="John%20H.%20Conway">John H. Conway</a>. 
The Griess algebra is the same as the degree 2 piece of the <a href="monster%20vertex%20algebra">monster vertex algebra</a>, and the Griess product is one of the vertex algebra products.
